This is a man who once worked out so hard during an offseason that he negatively effected his arm motion because his biceps where too…

paragraphs.text: Lets not over-complicate this. If a QB has a classic QB name that could double for a country singer, they will be good. Joe Montana’s the classic example here. If they have a shitty QB name, they will be shitty. I had no doubt Blake Bortles, Blaine Gabbert, and Jared Goff would suck before they even took a snap.

paragraphs.text: Can you compare Tom Brady’s performance at Michigan with Walsh and Parcells evaluation criteria? Walsh’s evaluation seems more qualitative while Parcell uses quantitative evaluations. Brady obviously didn’t approach most of Parcell’s requirements….then again, I suppose that’s why he was the 199th pick.

c718064a2e71.title: Can you compare Tom Brady’s performance at Michigan with Walsh and Parcells evaluation criteria?

paragraphs.text: McKinsey, likely the premiere talent evaluator of any company in the U.S., spends tons of time on “intangibles” of the candidates they evaluate. Yes they care about grade point averages, test scores, etc., but they also look at other factors to determine who is going to make it as a leader in the organization. No different here.

paragraphs.text: The comments panning Lombardi are completely unfair. I think this is a very good read. It is true that his statements are anecdotal but they are logical. I like that he makes a prediction in Watson. He is putting himself out there and making a call based on criteria which he explains. In this way he is not a psychic but an educated prognosticator.

virtuals.subtitle: Until you actually have anything tangible to back up your words this is a masturbatory exercise.

paragraphs.name: 4fb7
paragraphs.text: This is useless. No data, nothing to truly evaluate your statements. A lot of vague buzz words that could be interpreted to mean anything you want in a given situation. It’s the football equivalent of a TV psychic pretending to “hear” syllables whispered from the beyond before an overeager audience member blurts out “Sa? My Aunt Sarah died last year…

content.subtitle: Until you actually have anything tangible to back up your words this is a masturbatory exercise.

virtuals.subtitle: And I would definitely throw Tim Tebow at you if I had the arm strenght and a skin thick enough to pull it off.

paragraphs.name: 31b6
paragraphs.text: Is it a troll on Bill Barnwell? I can imagine Barnwell’s head exploding while reading that. The Ringer should hire him under a pseudonym to comment every item of this piece of s…scouting art. It’s a pity that “taking advantage of momentum swings” and “having the IT factor” haven’t made the list. Well, at least not explicitly.

b187e86062c7.title: Is it a troll on Bill Barnwell?

content.subtitle: And I would definitely throw Tim Tebow at you if I had the arm strenght and a skin thick enough to pull it off.

paragraphs.name: 4dfd
paragraphs.text: Great read! Counterpoint: NFL teams should mirror Dallas’ approach- search deep, deep inside yourself, then pull an NFL-caliber starter out of your ass. It’s worked twice now!

paragraphs.name: f4c9
paragraphs.text: Recently a top prospect — I won’t say who — was dinged by his college teammates. They hated him to the degree that they refused to attend any of his private workouts. That’s a huge red flag. An unfortunate NFL team ignored it and drafted him on Day 1. What happened? His new teammates ended up feeling just like his old ones. That’s a surprise? You don’t just suddenly flip from being a bad teammate to a good one.

paragraphs.name: 2c4f
paragraphs.text: Examine recent busts and show me a truly hard worker who failed. Ryan Leaf showed up 20 pounds overweight for his combine weigh-in; why wasn’t that a bigger red flag? Your franchise QB, if you can find one, should always be a gym rat. First to work, last to leave. He should be constantly working on his craft and constantly trying to improve. He should embrace hard work. And if he doesn’t, you’re screwed.

paragraphs.name: 81a7
paragraphs.text: Did you notice that arm strength failed to crack either list? Or that passing mechanics and delivery were absent? In the eyes of Walsh and Parcells, success and productivity override mechanics. And don’t throw Tim Tebow at me. Tebow succeeded in college as a runner, not a thrower. He failed in pro football not due to his mechanics (they certainly didn’t help), but because he had no feel for the passing game, no instincts, and zero willingness to improve. Tebow wanted to run with the ball, not sling it. That can’t work in the pros. We see the same mistakes happen in basketball evaluations. Does it matter that UCLA phenom Lonzo Ball’s shot mechanics look unorthodox when he keeps draining shots? Who cares? What’s the result?
